111.content:
Captain McLarwood stood at the bridge of his spaceship looking at the screen at the far side of the room. It displayed the view ahead. He like to stand here and watch the infinite emptiness of space. Around him the crew was doing their job perfectly. He hardly ever had to tell them anything. He walked back to his seat and sat down. The computer screen asked if he would like anything to eat or drink, it was programed as a servant and had no real practical function apart from keeping the captain comfortable. It was, perhaps a bit to intend on this thought McLarwood as he asked it for a soda. He had gained almost 15 pounds on his once lean body since the beginning of this mission one year ago. At least his crew wasn't going the same way, this was a luxury for captains only. The real reason the servant computer was there was so a captain would not have to leave his post during any dangerous situation, but it had no off function and was always offering.
He took a large drink from his soda and returned his stare to the screen. He was just about to leave the bridge and take a nap in his quarters when...
111.title: A spaceship

choices: 15 months later, the harvest is ready
112.content:
Richard Falsway stood watching the hills stretching out in front of him. By first look this might have been earth, but the three moons quickly gave it away this was not earth.
Behind him the construction team was almost finished putting up their new home. A whole small town had been constructed in just three days and they were ready to begin permanent habitation of the planet. It was a weird planet. It was twice as big as earth, only 20% water, all of it fresh, the planet did not have salt, and the only life was the plants. Not one kind of animals. not even germs. This planet was indeed a treasure. About 70% of the landmass was fertile plains and the remaining 30% of the landmass was steep hills and mountains, fitting for military instalations and safety shelters.
The plan was to turn the entire planet into a food source. That would not only end the ongoing starvation on earth and the other human colonies, the surplus harvest would make The Human Empire very rich.
Richard had signed up for this the moment he heard of it. He had always been a big eater and the starvation with it's food restrictions had been hard on him and the thought of not only ending it, but living in what was to become the biggest food storage in the galaxy was to tempting for him not to go. Half of the plains was to be used for cattle, and the construction team had a huge task ahead of them making more than 2000 Co2 cleansing machines across the planet to keep the cows from polluting it til death. They also had to build the farms, and the travelling system.
Richard was an expert in robotics, one of more than 1500 whose jobs was to make sure that the farming robots and other robots was working. There was nearly 15'000 people living on the planet now, most working with the technology required to make the farms work, manual labour was nearly non-existing. There was also wives and husbands of people working, and their children, about 500 of them. When making a colony like this it was easy to forget that you were actually creating a little town with shops, school, hospital, cinemas and other everyday stuff.
The leader of the planet was Admiral Carl McStack, but only untill the colony was ready have it's first election and choose a colonial leader. Richard knew he was not going to run for that job. He just wanted to do his job, get this planet working and have his first real meal in 5 years. He, like almost every human was only skin and bones, full meals was only for those who needed full strenght.
If everything went as planned they would be having the first harvest ready in 15 months.
Richard turns and walks into the town, not a pretty town, but a functional town, and finds his apartment. He steps into it. He has a ground floor apartment with two rooms, a combined kitchen and living room, and a bedroom. There was public bathrooms in the basement. He is tired from the long journey and lack of energy and goes to bed.
112.title: A new colony on a foreign planet

113.content:
There are many ways for a sci-fi station to exist, what fits your fancy?

You are Michael Zambac, a skillful engineer who has been transferred to, or traveled to, one of the stations below. He's in good health with above average looks, never struggled with relationships. His expertise is need for his next assignment. Michael also has a bit of a preference for larger women.

Station Omicron: A Startrek-style, high standard of living, research station orbiting a white dwarf, the researches are studying various different specimens and technologies. These currently include studies on Zeta Waves, Bacteria Cultures, and Exotic Foods; among many other things. Each project has a head researcher who has a seat on a council who rule the station, though it is plagued with the many downfalls of large councils and bureaucracies.
Your job will be maintenance on some of the delicate machines in the labs.

Station Nu: A Mass Effect-styled station, a little grungy, a little clean, depends where you are on the station. This station is a major trade hub along a galactic highway, with millions, if not billions, of credits passing through everyday. "Strange Aliens, Strange People, Strange Foods, Strange Products, everything passes Through Nu", they say. Not really they, only the station manager Jason Shrux.
Your job will be Security System IT.

Station Mu: After a near apocalyptic ecological and economic collapse, humanity is on the brink of disappearing. Station Mu currently houses one of the largest human colonies in it's region of the galaxy. However, it is wrought with old parts, a failing power grid, and a birth rate that has been on the decline. A new corporation, RestoreTech, is promising to be able to get the station fully operational and a thriving hub for humanity ... but a what cost?
You were already on this station when RestoreTech arrived, we'll see what happens.

Again, the author wants full originality, I used "Startrek-style" and "Mass Effect-style" so that you can get an image of what I have in mind.
113.title: The Station in Space

choices: Spend some time in your room, wait for Candice to find you tomorrow

1131.content:
You looked out the holo-window at the station, a marvel of human engineering. The huge station starts with a two mile long central shaft, with five large rings attached to it. The first three rings are for research, each one falling under a different type of study, with many projects going on in each. The fourth ring is for habitation, and the fifth for vital system (life support, hydroponics, power generation, etc.). Your shuttle went to the docking bay at the bottom of the main shaft and docked. The airlock opened and you entered, being the only person on board the shuttle. Once through decontamination, you passed through another airlock to a receiving area. A pretty brunette-haired woman held a tablet against her chest and greeted you.

"You must be Mr. Zambac, welcome to Station Omicron." she smiled

"It looks as impressive as I heard it was." you reply with a smirk.

"There's a lot more to this station than meets the eye." she responded, curling her smile a little more, "If you'll follow me, I'll get you situated in your quarters." she turned and started walking. You followed, taking a peak at her shapely rear as you caught up to her. You enter and elevator, which takes you sideways, "This elevator will take us to the tram station, there are four tram lines on this station, allowing for maximum efficiency." she said with a hint of pride. You nod in response as the elevator stops and you follow her out. There's a few other people on the platform waiting for the tram, mostly women. Some notice your presence. The tram arrives shortly and people enter one end and leave through another. "We'll be heading to Habitation first, then to Ms. Erin to get your work assignments."

"I hear the accommodations are pretty good here." you remark, looking around the spartanesque tram.

"Station Omicron enjoys one of the highest standards of living amongst all human research stations." she said with a prideful smile. The tram stopped at the three research rings, exchanging passengers each time, and finally made it's way to the Habitation Ring. "Here is our stop, if you will follow me, again." she said standing and leading you out of the tram station. The habitation ring seemed like a cramped, but orderly apartment complex and a luxury hotel both at the same time, with many hallways lined just as many doors, but you knew each door led to it's own high class living space. "Here is yours: H13R8008" she hands you a key card. "Most of everything you need has been provided, I see you brought a bag of personal effects?"

"Yea, my favorite tools and some other things." you say, looking around the large room, "Never had a place this big all to my own..."

"Yes well, if you get lonely..." she pauses, then hesitates, "th-there's a large common area with plenty of opportunities to socialize."

"I'll probably spend my off time there, used to more cramped conditions." you reminisce

"Yes well, uh, I forgot to introduce myself, my name is Candice. I'll come find you tomorrow for your work assignments." she says and lets herself out. You walk into the bedroom and lay your bag at the foot of your bed and lay down on it and letting out a huge sigh, wondering what to do with yourself.

11311.content: You had the rest of the evening to yourself, so you decide to get up out of bed and get a feel for your new home. Looking around the bedroom, you find a master bath and a small closet. The bathroom has the usual amenities, you're surprised to find a rather large shower, "Woulda thought a single would be fine, but you could fit three of me in there.." you muse as you go out into the main room of the apartment. It was a bit taller than rooms usually are, with a sofa face an entertainment system against the wall to the bedroom. Behind it was the kitchen, with a table and one chair, though there was controls for adding more. Turning around, you realize "kitchen" may have been a bit generous, it was simply a bar for the food materializer. It was stylish enough, however, and you get some dinner from it and eat it in silence. You really were not used to having such nice personal quarters. You felt like a king. After finishing, you look around a bit more, finding the guest bathroom and taking in the simple decorations of the main room.

You ride the tram down to the Biological Research Ring, and exit, wandering around and fiddling with your access card. You always had to have something to fiddle with in your hands, always.

1151.content:
Sam Cavell could hardly stand still. He was about to go down in history as the first human to make proper contact with the Eraxi. He and the 5 other members of the delegation was just minutes away from landing at the space port of the Eraxi homeworld, Eraxus. The Eraxi was a humanoid race, and not so unlike humans. They had the same basic, so it was no need for any special accommodations like air suits or expensive habit dome to live in. To make time go faster Sam went over what he knew about the Eraxi in his head. They breath air and drink water, similar food, at times remarkably like Indian food. wealthy, from decades of surplus production of food for export to other races. Homeworld Eraxus three times bigger than Earth, but with equal population. Nature and animal life remarkably similar to earth.
A red light began to flash, signaling that they were just seconds away from docking.
The Eraxus space port was a large space station going in orbit around the largest of Eraxus three moons. A thud and a jolt and the door began to open.
Sam took a deep breath, adjusted the tie on his suit and prepared to be the first human to meet an Eraxi face to face, or at least face to chest, as Eraxi was taller than humans.
The door opened all the way, and Sam stepped out, followed by the rest of the delegation. The Eraxi was waiting for them. Sam took in the sight, tall human like beings. Their build was mostly like humans, but they were taller, had longer necks, 7 fingers on each hand, their nose was just to holes located under their moth, and their ears were high on their head, covered by hair. Their hair color was mostly dark green dark purple, but apart from color it was like human hair. The only other thing Sam noted was that they were all quite overweight, the smallest of them sporting a belly the size of a football.
Sam walked 3 steps toward the leader of the greeters. He then bowed his head. The leader of their greeters, a hugely fat Eraxi, walked or more precise waddled, three steps toward Sam and bowed his head. Then they both looked up, walked to the middle of the room and shook hands, the tradional Eraxi way was to press their foreheads into each other, but the height diffrence made that difficult, so the Eraxi had offered to adapt the human handshake when welcoming humans.
The leader turned and began walking towards the door, motioning for Sam to follow, according to Eraxi custom, it was rude to talk to special guests until you had offered them food, and it was also terribly rude do decline this offer.

122112.content:
"Ah Finally!" extoled Sabrina.

Upon setting foot on the ground Sabrina felt a pleasant breeze. The temperature was perfect. Sabrina could already feel her troubles float away.

"Oh my!" exclaimed the blonde "I didn't imagine it would feel this good."

The girls' delight was interrupted by an obese woman dragging along her daughter.

"But mommyyy! I don't want to go!" shrieked a chunky girl as her thick arm was dragged by her mother.

"Sorry dear but we're leaving. We can't stay on this planet another minute." commanded the rotund woman as she yanked her daughter to the ship.

"But I want ice cream!" screamed the girl.

Suddenly a robot floated to the girl and handed her a huge ice cream cone. The girl then grabbed the ice cream cone with her free hand and ate it.

"No! Please you must resist! You can't eat all the time." cried the mother whose cries were halted by her rumbling stomach.

Noticing the woman's needs, a robot dashed to her bearing a tray of various foods.

"Please no." gasped the woman.

The robot nudged the tray to her face.

"Please stop." she pleaded but ostensibly gazed upon the delicious foods.

The robot ignored the woman's words as her facial expressions signaled hunger. The woman broke and stuffed her face from the robot's offerings. After a few minutes of rapid gorging, the woman finished. The woman than noticed that Sabrina had watched the whole scene.

"Leave this planet." the woman spoke "Leave. I was once thin like you. It was only a year ago that I moved here with my daughter. We were only trying to escape our hard life, but we became addicted to the robot slaves and before we knew it our thin bodies had become this way." The woman grabbed her belly roll to emphasize her point.

"Y-yyyeeeaaah, sure." Sabrina ignored the woman's ominous warning having dismissed the woman as some crazy fatty.

The woman then shoved her way through the crowd boarding the ship dragging her fat daughter behind.

"Out of my way." she ordered bumping people aside with her plump body.

"What a weird lady. Huh. Oh well now what do I do?" Sabrina asked herself.

Sabrina looked to the blonde...
122112.title: A sign of things to come

1221121.content:
"I guess she couldn't handle it." said the blonde attempting to explain the scene that had just taken place. "She probably ran out of things to do and let herself go."

"Yeah that sounds logical." Sabrina agreed.

"There's no way I'd let that happen to me. I have so much to do to start my new life here." the blonde smiled as a personal self operating car pulled up to her.

Sabrina waved goodbye to the blonde she shared only but a few moments with. A selfdriving car pulled up to Sabrina, ready to take her wherever. As Sabrina sat down she could feel the soft cushion close in around her ass, wrapping the posterior in a comfortable position. It was also air conditioned set to the perfect temperature for Sabrina due to its high tech body heat sensors.

The self driving vehicle had taken Sabrina to an empty lot next to houses. This was were her house would be built. A group of robots arrived each with the ability to mind link with Sabrina to read her mind and build her house to the best extent that would accomodate her tastes. In mere moments, the astounding robots constructed a lavish residence for Sabrina.

"Oh my its perfect!" she exclaimed.

Running into her house Sabrina experienced pure bliss as everything catered to her every senses. It looked gorgeous, there was pleasant music, and there was a variety of tantalizing scents.

"I can't believe how wonderful this is." Sabrina teared up from her well deserved fortune, realizing she truly was no longer burdened by those previous jobs.

The pleasant smells had caused Sabrina to become hungry. Sabrina went into the kitchen to cook something. Heading towards the oven Sabrina intended on making a huge celebratory meal. However once Sabrina reached the counter everything began moving. The entire kitchen was self operating doing all of the work for its occupant.

"Oh I guess I don't have to do anything." Sabrina said as a automated chair popped behind her, sitting her down in a cushioned pillow.

The chair wheeled Sabrina to the table were her feast was brought to her. The spread was amazing, far better than she could've made. Despite its delicious taste, Sabrina only managed to eat a third of it. The robots swiftly removed the food and tossed it in recycling while cleaning the table leaving it sparkling clean.

"Oh wow I didn't have to do a thing."

Sabrina then felt like taking a nice hot bath. But before she even lifted a finger, the chair transported her to the tub which was already prepared. The water was perfectly temped and there was a wide variety of soaps and lotions. The bath was paired with soothing music and satisfying scents. The robots undressed Sabrina who felt slightly uneased by how forward the robots were. But the second Sabrina submersed herself in the water she relinquished any concerns she had.

This was Sabrina's new life. Carefree. Comfortable. Effortless.

His trip out of the colony has been uneventful to say the least, having not found anything of significance.

1322.title: Koty, 6 days into his exploration

13222.content:
With day turning to night, Koty was beginning to lose hope of finding anything.

"I don't think I'm gonna find find anything. I'm just going to head back to the colony." Koty said, defeated

Just as Koty said that though, he caught a glimmer of something just over a large hill. Filled with a new resolve, he bounds towards whatever is over the hill

"Whoa..." Was all Koty could say for what he saw

Over the hill laid a large, derelict space ship. The ship appears to have been there for several years, with plant life overgrowing most of the ship.

"Alright let's see if I can get in there!" Koty said with a grin and a spark in his eye.

Koty begins by looking around the ship for any openings or holes in the ship. Luckily there was a access panel linked to one of the doors.

The inside of the ship was almost as bad as the exterior, with broken machinery everywhere and mysterious liquids on the ground.

"Eh uh Eva, you read me?" Koty said, speaking into his communicator.

"Loud and clear Koty, ready to be picked up?"

"Actually, I found an old ship."

"Really?! Oh my god Koty, that's amazing!"

"Hehehe thanks."

"We'll have an extraction team there soon. Why don't you keep looking around until they get there."

"Got it Eva, I'll see you back at the colony soon. Koty out."

Koty then does as Eva said and goes deeper into the ship.

The rest of the ship looks similar to the room Koty entered, except for the occasional skittering animal...but one room was different. Koty eventually came across an ominous door. The door appears to be heavily armored and with an odd set of symbols, but one symbol stood out. In the middle of the door is a circular shape with 5 smaller circles around it and one long line going from one circle then all the way up the door to a large shape with many smaller geometric lines covering it. Koty doesn't know why, but he's getting an odd feeling from this door. The door feels like tempting him to open the door, to see what's on the other side, but what if there something dangerous. Koty then gives in and opens the door, against his better judgment

The room is incredibly large, probably making up a third of the ship, and appears to be completely untouched from the years of degradation. The room is also pretty barren, with absolutely nothing in the room.

"Huh...I thought there'd be something in here." Koty said in a disappointed tone.

Not feeling so cautious anymore, Koty stupidly begins to meander around the room.

"Hehe I guess I didn't need to be so scared." Koty said as he reached the center of the room.

Just as Koty reached the center, a sky blue light paralyzed him in place!

"Wha...what the hell?!" Koty said as he tried his best to get free, but it's no use.

Koty then begins to float up into the air, and stops when he's 5 feet off the ground. Koty then begins to hear a loud mechanical sound above him. When he looks up, the whole ceiling had opens up to reveal a massive machine with two large tanks, one filled with red liquid and another with blue liquid. When the machine stops it's descent, it then reveals a long clear tube from a hatch in the front...the tube then begins to slowly work it way towards Koty's mouth. No matter how hard he tries, Koty can't move his head away from the tube and can only watch as it slowly enters his mouth. choices: Shira is currently working as a captain of her own ship.

141.content: Shira is a female Xaithan, a species that closely resemble anthropomorphic dragons – scale covered bodies, wings, muzzles, tail, so on – except for the fact that many of their body parts are doubled when compared to the Terran depictions; two pairs of eyes, two pairs of arms, female Xaithans usually posses two pairs of more human looking breasts, even their internal organs tend to be doubled. The Xaithan also were mostly a society that appreciated or even required their women to be fat, depending on the region, as a sign of the family’s prestige and prosperity. The Xaithan homeworld Xocha– and by extension the home system of the same name – only joined the Galactic Alliance a little under 100 standard years ago, and very few Xaithan have traveled out of their system, so they are still somewhat a novelty throughout the space lanes.
141.title: Shira the Xaithan

choices: Shira is finally given permission to land.
She is being directed to move to a different orbital position and wait there.
It’s a message from out of system.
1411.content:
Shira huffed for the umpteenth time since she arrived in orbit, her nostrils flaring. It was supposed to be a simple delivery job of some heavy farm machinery, but what the contract hadn’t mentioned was the destination was some fringe world mired in so much bureaucracy that any ships arriving tended to have to wait half a galactic standard day or more before even landing, and then there was the inspections, customs, and on and on. The Xaithan should have known something was up with how much was being paid for the job, but her unease was outweighed by her desire to want to eat this month as well as getting some repairs done to her ship – loosely translated as The Red Arrow – that some recent inspectors had been hounding her about, citing public safety hazards and other regulations. Shira knew exactly how much she could push her ship though, knowing it inside and out after personally restoring and rebuilding much of what a used to be a ship that was considered by many useless for even parts.

“Any change, yet?” Shira called out into the still and quiet bridge.

“No, captain, we are still being told to hold position,” a steady feminine voice said from the overhead speakers.

Shira still grinned slightly whenever she heard herself being called “captain”. It was technically true, and she often slipped it into conversation usually as a pick-up line, but it rang a bit hollow considering that it was often just her forming the entire crew on the Arrow, except for a few special cases that might require a specialist for containment of the cargo or something. The only exception was Shira’s personal AI, Nova, a simple but effective artificial intelligence that Shira had cobbled together out of spare parts. While Nova was many magnitudes less powerful than similar government or military AIs, she was perfectly capable of running the more mundane aspects of both the Arrow and Shira’s life: sensors, repeating hails, scheduling, and so on. The little AI also helped keep Shira sane on the long interstellar journeys, just as someone to talk to, even if she was just a somewhat intelligent computer system.

Shira shifted in her chair and huffed again; one arm propped her head up, leaning on an armrest, two more were keeping busy with a puzzle cube that she had picked up a bazaar on one of her stops recently, while the last was trying to sooth her stomach which continued to voice its displeasure with not being fed yet. Shira hailed from one of the Northern provinces of Xocha, specifically one that didn’t put quite as much focus on a female Xaithan’s weight compared to some of the other regions of her homeworld, but it still played a part. Shira had always been a misfit growing up though, so while she could easily be considered fat by the majority of species out in the galaxy, she was downright skeletal compared to the majority of her own species’ women. Her own mother was barely able to walk without assistance, and her younger sister (only by two years as she liked to remind anyone who would listen) looked to be well on her way to matching or beating their mother’s records. In the states where it was more of a requirement, young Xaithan women were often fattened nearly to if not past immobility by the time they were of marriageable age, and most did it with glee. Shira hadn’t quite taken to the prospect with the same zeal, wanting to explore the galaxy beyond and see strange new worlds and the people that inhabited them. Perhaps in time, she might consider settling down and letting her instincts take more control till she was a bloated ball of blubber, but for now she was content to pilot her ship throughout the galaxy.

Shira tossed the cube away in annoyance, mostly with the planetary travel authority rather than the puzzle cube which was proving spectacularly easy to the Xaithan, and watched the puzzle tumble slowly through the microgravity. A whirl of photons appeared beside her chair, and as it resolved, Nova appeared in her standard appearance of a small mote of light with some little fluttering wings.

“You can head back and get something to eat if you wish, captain. I will notify you if we are ever cleared to land.” Nova said in her soft tones, a slight chuckle at her little joke came as well.

“No, I would rather be here so we can get moving whenever or if we can,” Shira responded.

With an annoyed grunt, the Xaithan unclipped the harness holding her down and, with the tiniest of nudges, drifted to the forward viewport, stopping with the help of a slight touch of a hand to the deckhead above. The view outside was still what Shira had been seeing for the past while: ships of all sizes, ranging from smaller family-style planet skippers to massive cargo freighter ships that made the Arrow look like a single person ship in comparison (those giant ships would have to dock and offload at one of the orbital stations rather than landing), all orbiting a rather typical inhabited world below. Only a few ships had moved out of this high orbit holding pattern since she had arrived, though more than number that had been added in the same time.

Shira now turned her gaze to the ghostly reflection of herself in the glossy panel. She scowled a bit as she saw how close her clothes were getting to being ill fitting across her rotund frame; something else she would have to be purchasing soon. Two of her hands were put to use finger-combing the thick curls of black hair sprouting from her head, while a third itched the band of shorter softer hair going down her spine and out across the top of her muscular tail. Shira ended up getting a little lost in rubbing several of her hands across her soft and deep-blue scales to try and stimulate her blood flow to keep herself awake, that she almost missed the soft chiming notification of an incoming message.

“Shira, did you hear me? There is a hail coming in,” Nova announced, her holographic avatar zipping up to bob in front of Shira’s face.

“Yeah, I heard you. Put it through.”
1411.title: Going nowhere fast

14111.content:
“Galactic Trade Vessel Red Arrow proceed to the coordinates using the flight path being sent to your navigation computer. Your progress to the destination will be monitored, and any deviation from the flight path will be met with repercussions,” said the droll audio only broadcast, which clicked off without even signing off.

Shira pushed off of the deckhead and used her wings just a bit to direct herself just a bit so that she drifted right into her seat.

After strapping in, she glanced over at Nova who responded without being asked, “Coordinates received, confirming flight path and applying overlay.”

As the little computer spoke, a holographic HUD appeared in the viewport, highlighting nearby obstacles, as well as displaying a path of floating green squares denoting the route. Satisfied with the set-up, Shira keyed in the start-up sequence, feeling the slight tremor as the core spun up. That mild shaking increased as she hit the throttle, a constant reassuring rumble that she could feel in her back teeth. There was a subtle pressure pushing her into the seat as the Arrow darted through the crowd of other ships drifting before slipping out of orbit and into the atmosphere below. Now gravity was starting to take hold, the noise of the engines shifting as they now had to keep the ship in the air.

The air lanes proved to be full of traffic once in the atmosphere, but the Arrow was light and agile enough that Shira had no problem navigating to the port at the coordinates. Once there, she landed with barely a thump, before going through the unloading process. The Trox dockmaster tried to be surly, and it might have succeeded – he was exceptionally tall and muscular for a Trox – except for the fact that the average Trox only stood three feet tall. This particular fine example stood probably a hair over four feet tall, but Shira stood just short of nine feet tall—about two shriks in her species’ units of measurement. He also seemed a bit unnerved by which pair of eyes to look at, something that almost always proved troubling to most binocular species that she had encountered so far. It probably didn’t help that xaithan could move each of the two pairs could independently of the other so she could look at two things at the same time with no trouble.

He tried to give her grief over the delay in the shipment as well as how the containers had been ordered in the bay, but she told him to take it up with the workers at the Nal Gate station that had put the containers in like that, as well as the orbital traffic controllers that kept everything so slowed down. The Trox sputtered and tried another angle, but Shira mostly ignored him and went back to supervising the offloading. With that finished, she checked in with the transportation company she worked with, confirmed that her credits had been transferred, and noted that she had even received a bonus for completing the job earlier than expected—despite what the dockmaster had tried to blame her for. With an added spring in her step, Shira locked up her ship and radioed Nora to say that she was heading out since there were no other jobs on her plate yet.

Chrido was a more arid world that Shira was used to, but the slightly below average gravity was a welcome change from the several high-gravity worlds that she had been to recently. The space port was welcoming as well – once you got into it – and provided a number of services for those plying the local space lanes. All of that traffic inevitably attracted the wrong sort of people as well, so Shira checked that her plasma blasters were still clipped to her hips; she also much more discreetly checked the less-than-legal disruptor hand cannons were holstered beneath her vest and under her second pair of arms. The second set of weapons weren’t something that she had to often use, but when she did, she was always extremely glad she had them—they cut through personal energy shields like almost as well as military grade weapons. She wasn’t planning on getting into any trouble anyways, but it always paid to be prepared.

A quick check on the local datanet pointed her to a local tavern that was suited to species like her own, just the place to wet her whistle as well maybe seeing about a new job. She didn’t want to stumble into a bar for some of the more exotic species out in this region of the galaxy; early on in her life away from her home, she went to the wrong place and ended up horribly sick and nearly passing out from the fumes that some species thrived in, but were toxic to most others. Night was starting to fall when she arrived at “Droka’s Place”. Inside a number of people from across the galaxy, no other xaithans though but that wasn’t odd at all. There were even a few Alliance troopers in the center, celebrating their shore leave from the looks of things. Walking up to the bar, she motioned towards the bartender – Droka presumably – and he poured and slid a tall glass her way; it contained a local brew, pale blue with a thin mist pouring over the edge of the glass. From what she had read, it was not something to be sipped and savored, more tipped and gulped, so she did so, though it felt like she had swallowed a blaster bolt from how it burned her throat on the way down. She hissed through her teeth slightly but ordered another. As she readied herself for the second slug, she felt as if someone was watching her. A casual glance one way then the other showed no one paying any particular attention to her, some had starred a bit when she first came in, but most had never seen a xaithan, so she had gotten used to that reaction quickly, this felt different though. Then she saw her watcher, across the room and beyond the Alliance soldiers, they were almost hidden in the shadows in the back corner, but there was no mistaking the glint of the sparse light off of those eyes pointed straight at her.
14111.title: Moving on

143.content:
Your character has been selected for a position on the human space station 42. Before we get to deciding who she is, perhaps we could take a moment to decide what kind of station she will be serving on.

Is this a research station? Humanity is a relatively recent addition to the Galactic community, but has proven to be quite ingenious. Dangerously so, many believe, but it hasn't stopped many species from establishing embassies and research treaties with this oft-times disturbing species. Is the MC a brave, or perhaps nervous, scientist heading for such an opportunity? Or is she merely a functionary, there to enable the facility to continue to function and the research team to conduct their work without worrying about such matters as food?

Is this a diplomatic outpost? Humanity entered the stars at a rather terrible time, often referred to as the War in Heaven. Two of the great empires of old had begun a Galaxy spanning conflict, with the victor claiming the whole of inhabited space as their prize. However, neither race had expected the rise of the Earthlings. Even after their homeworld was enslaved, the Humans continued to fight back with a tenacity none had been expecting.

Defeat, casualties, enslavement, nothing seemed to end the human will to be masters of their own destiny. As their partisans bled their enemies white, the free worlds constructed massive fleets, bending their every ounce of brilliance and cruel ingenuity to developing an unstoppable force. It took three generations (by human measurements), but at long last the Earthlings reclaimed their home and shattered the Empires of Old.

On the one hand, the Galaxy breathed a sigh of relief, as a hundred species no longer lived in fear. On the other, the millennia old order has ended, and the universe stands on the edge of an unknown future. Many fear the Earthlings will install themselves as the new overlords of inhabited space, while others fear they won't. Then what?

The Earthlings first move in the wake of their shocking victory was a rather unorthodox one. They constructed Space Station 42, a sprawling monolith capable of supporting a population in the millions. They then invited all species able to do so to send ambassadors and establish embassies. They claim the aim is peaceful coexistence, but who knows what these maniacs truly have in mind?

Is the MC one such ambassador? Or perhaps she's an aide, or minor functionary? Perhaps a reporter, eager to find a story to wow her fans back home? Or maybe she's just a general nobody, hoping to make her way in this strange new world?

Is this a trade outpost? The worlds of the Galaxy are loaded with many lavish resources and untold treasures, but the distribution is anything but even. Many species rely on things which are exceedingly rare HERE, but very common over THERE. And if one group's trash is another group's gold?

Well, that's where the real money can be made.

Wolden-Dorff Dressler understands this simple truth better then anyone. Arguably the most successful corporation in the Galaxy, they were the ones who developed a cost-effective form of planetary terraforming, what is often referred to as a Shake-and-Bake colony. They've pioneered new mining practices, efficient FTL technology, established the Util as the Galactic currency, and are largely responsible for humanity's expansion across the stars.

They've also been accused of starting proxy wars, debt slavery, chattel slavery, occasional genocide, extremely exploitative work and environmental practices, and talking on their cell phones while in a movie theatre. They of course deny all such accusations, and such is their wealth and power in human space that the Federation government refuses any calls to investigate the monolithic corporate giant.

Indeed, many worlds and systems are owned outright by the corporation, and the bulk of the Federation's Utils and raw resources are owned by either WDD or a subsidiary, but the real jewel in the Board's crown is their massive and complex network of trade outposts. Lying on the nexus points of the slip stream tunnels and equipped with large merchant fleets, nearly every good in human space is transported on a WDD vessel, for a fee of course. As befitting their importance, the stations are lavishly appointed, and the posts on board are high paying and fiercely contested.

However, Space Station 42 is not one such station.

42 sits at the entrance of the dark nebula known simply as Nowhere. The nebula proved to simultaneously be shockingly rich in intelligent life and distressingly bare in any valuable resources. Public outcry against WDD's vile business practices, whether true or not, has at last forced the glacial Federation congress to issue a law forbidding the corporation's direct interference with the other intelligent races of the Galaxy.

This has left Space Station 42 in a bit of a rough spot, as it represents a considerable investment with no real means of making a return on it. What few resources are within reach are now off limits in the wake of the new law, and there aren't many opportunities for expansion in the area. Many in the corp are calling for the potential money sink to be shut down, while others wish to keep the facility running even at a small profit, at least until the company recoups its investment. So far, there are no voices saying that this backwater can be made profitable.

Or is there one?

Perhaps the MC is the new station master, getting her foot in the door by accepting the post no one wanted, eager to prove she can bring this place back in the black? Or maybe she's lower down the corporate ladder? IT? Security? A mechanic, perhaps? Or maybe an independent, opening a small business on the station's docking ring? The only limit is your imagination, after all.

So, which is it?
143.title: Welcome to Space Station 42

1433.content:
Well, now that we know what kind of station the MC will be serving on, who is the main character of our widening feature? For ease of understanding, all measurements of age, height and weight will be in common human terms.

Chel Nat'yochtli
Species: Naxian
Station Position: Mechanical Department, Foreman
6 adult years, long green "hair", 5'9" tall, 120 pounds

The Naxians are an amphibious species which entered the galaxy around the same time as humanity. As a species, they are very invested in their accomplishments, often to an unhealthy degree. This path was laid for them by the Great Paragon, Anarathustra, the Bridge Maker. By definition, they see a life with no accomplishments as inherently meaningless and wasteful, if not outright destructive to society as a whole. The Path even establishes minimums with regards to quantity and quality of accomplishments over time, and committing suicide to maintain personal honour after failing to meet your minimums is quite common.

WDD, as you might imagine, found the Naxians to be fairly malleable to the corporate mindset. Not only were they fanatically devoted to their personal success and the success of the company, their high birth rate meant that the corp was never lacking for dedicated employees.

Chel is a little unusual amongst her species. She is technically a failure, never truly excelling at school and failing to meet any of the Path's minimums. Most infuriating for her fellow Naxians, she adamantly refused to save her honour via death. Estranged from the bulk of her family, she took this job on Space Station 42 in order to support herself while trying to figure out what she's truly passionate about. Maintenance of slip stream drives was one of the very few activities in which she excelled, so she was promoted to foreman despite her lack of experience, given the lack of anyone else fit for the position on this godforsaken backwater.

Chel has light blue skin, with an assortment of pink spots which change shape according to her mood. Her general body form is fairly humanoid, with only a handful of minor differences. Her hair, however, is not actually hair. It is in fact a symbiotic plant, which can supplement her caloric intake via photosynthesis. Her skin, like earth amphibians, is permeable, and she is vulnerable to absorbing chemicals and the like through her living skin layer.


Xul
Species: Hunniq
Station Position: Station Master
39 years, Hairless, 6'8", 265 lbs.

Many in her Clan said she was mad to ask for this post, but Xul didn't care.

The Hunniq race is, for the most part, only concerned with survival. Their homeworld is the desert planet Hullack. Basic resources like water are extremely scarce, and inter-clan raids and skirmishes were a daily fact of life. It is perhaps Hullack's tough conditions which led to the reptilian species rather low birthrate and high ratio of males to females. To take Xul as an example, her mother had five husbands and six children, of which Xul was one of only two girls.

As you might imagine, there is quite a strong push in their society to take many mates (the concept of marriage being rather foreign to them), so Xul deciding to wait was not well received. Truthfully, she does wish to have a family someday, but she doesn't feel she needs to sacrifice her personal success in order to do so. She hasn't told her mother, but she intends to establish her first Warren-bond once she succeeds at bringing Station 42 into profit, though she merely selected someone she was fond of (the concept of love also being a foreign concept) rather then following tradition and forcing bloody contests between her suitors.

Like most Hunniq, she is a towering and intimidating specimen. Females tend to be 30-45% larger then males, and far more muscular, and Xul is no exception. Her skin is covered with armoured scales like gravel, and her bald head is crested with six towering, curly horns. The Hunniq are exothermic, and her suits inevitably have an environmental mesh to adjust her temperature as needed.

She is quite close with her Clan despite their differences. She exchanges messages constantly with her beloved younger sister, Zhul. She also frequently communicates with her mother, though the two fight more often then not, Khul simply refusing to understand why her elder daughter might not want to merely lord over her own warband. Despite this, it is quite rare that the two will outright refuse to message one another.

A final note of the Hunniq species is that they principally communicate via scent. This led to some severe misunderstandings during first contact, with the humans assuming the Hunniq were totally unintelligent. By their standards, Xul is very chatty and she understands better then most Hunniq the importance of verbal communication. The fact that most species consider Hunniq pheromones to be rather foul smelling is another drawback.


Left blank for any other ideas you may have.
1433.title: Make out the cheque to...

choices: A new colony on a foreign planet
15.content:
Alien hermaphrodite

Now choose the setting you wish. If choosing "something else" remember to use the last space in the choices for people who want something else.
15.title: Alien hermaphrodite

info.description:
It's the future. Travel the stars on a space ship, live on a foreign planet, work on a space station or explore places where no man has ever gone before. All while gaining weight.

Rules:
Weightgain does not have to be realistic, but make sure that there is an option for both natural and unatural gain
Everyone can gain
Both gay and straight stuff allowed but don't be to pornographic, this is foremost a sci-fi weight gain story
Death only if it fits the story
A story must be at least 20 chapters long before ending
Apart from weight related stuff, keep fetish stuff minimal
Aliens allowed, even as maincharacter
When writing aliens, remember to desribe them. Make up your own aliens, I don't want Daleks, Klingons, Ewoks or other copyrighted creatures here.


A little tip: the maincharacter does not have to be the one gaining weight, he/she/it can for instance be a spaceship captain fattening he/she/it's crew.

I reserve the right to delete or rewrite chapters that are poorly writen or messes up a storyline.
